Award.AwardTitle: Quantitative analysis of the Costa Rica margin 3D seismic volume to reveal subduction zone structure, tectonics, and the development of the seismogenic zone
Award.AbstractNarration:
Subduction zones are where major earthquakes and tsunami generation occur but the regional human risk varies since geologic and hydrologic conditions vary along a given margin. The presence of (possibly lubricating) fluid within the 'megathrust fault' where the Pacific plate slides down beneath Costa Rica will be documented and related to the pattern of seismicity. Above the megathrust fault, many smaller faults control deformation within the sedimentary wedge. This study will provide new understanding of this margin's evolution and a more complete picture of the range of hazards will be obtained. Training of next generation marine scientists will take place via involvement of undergraduate students in the data analysis and a postdoctoral scholar will play a significant role throughout the study.

Analysis of the structure of an offshore portion of the Costa Rica margin will document fluid pathways within and at the base of the sedimentary wedge that forms the toe of the tectonic plate that overrides the megathrust fault. Advanced analysis of the 3-D multi-channel seismic reflection dataset previously collected by the R/V Langseth will be conducted. Prior study determined the geometry of the megathrust and this study will quantify physical properties within the fault zone. Amplitude versus offset results should discern whether portions of the megathrust fault are fluid bearing. The relation with seismicity patterns will address the possible role of fluids in controlling historical slip along the fault. Detailed structural modeling of the accretionary wedge, which is riddled with small faults, will be conducted to show how deformation of the overriding plate is accommodated over time. Re-analysis of a legacy ocean bottom seismic refraction profile will provide comparison to velocity structure in a neighboring part of the margin so that along-strike variability can be assessed. The findings will provide key context for interpretations of past and possible future scientific ocean drilling results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to use our recently acquired and fully processed 3D seismic reflection data volume to quantitatively investigate the structures within the Costa Rica Pacific margin to reveal the structural, depositional, and tectonic development within this subduction zone. The Costa Rica margin is thought to be a type example of a subduction zone that has been eroding the margin tectonically and removing pieces of the margin with subduction. It is a type of margin that is believed to occur in more than half of the world’s subduction zones; however, the structural, tectonic, and depositional development are not well understood in these settings. Understanding the structural and tectonic development of erosional and non-accretionary subduction zones is critical for complementing previous studies of accretionary subduction zones and fully characterizing the range of setting for megathrust earthquakes and tsunamis. This project is focused on understanding these processes.

This project used a recently acquired 3D seismic data volume to analyze some of the critical structures within the Costa Rica margin. The main goal was to examine the effects of subducting basement ridges and seamounts on the tectonics and structural record left behind in the Costa Rica subduction zone as a type example of erosive or non-accretionary subduction zones. These results will be particularly helpful in interpreting and understanding the rock record in all subduction zones with respect to assessing the history of ridge and seamount collisions. Ridges and seamounts are known to have a role in controlling the extent of earthquake rupture propagation and are a critical component for understanding earthquake hazards.

Our primary findings reveal that ridge collisions have played a very large role in the development of the Costa Rica subduction zone. We focused on applying a data analysis technique that allowed us to identify faults within the most recent sequences of sediments that have been deposited on the shelf and slope over the past two million years. We were able to identify and map 17,000 distinct normal faults throughout the 11 x 50 km 3D volume. The faults showed stress patters that have developed during several periods throughout the last two million years. One set of faults follows a N-S trend. These faults are known to be caused by a major subduction-related, ridge collision between a very large ridge on the subducting plate, the Cocos Ridge, which is actively colliding with the Costa Rica margin. The axis of the ridge is currently being subducted 30 km to the SE of the 3D data volume. These fault patterns are consistent with observations from recent drilling during the International Ocean Discovery Program expeditions. However, we have also discovered a second set of normal faults that are more localized throughout the volume and are oriented primarily E-W. On the basis of their relationship to fold patterns and local unconformities, these faults are believed to be a result of collision and subduction of basement ridges much smaller than the Cocos Ridge, and possibly small seamounts that have subducted within the survey area within the past two million years.

Complementary work supports this interpretation. Kinematic modeling showed the extensive shortening and possible removal of material associated with ridge/seamount collision. Work conducted at the University of California at Santa Cruz showed the development of local basins and surface erosional unconformities related to uplift and subsidence associated with the passage of ridges and seamounts. Discrete element modeling with collaborators at Rice University also showed specific tectonic responses to ridge/seamount collision and subduction that aided in interpreting the tectonic processes. These results have now all been published. Collectively these results have shown us the impacts of ridge/seamount collisions on subduction zones that can be interpreted in terms of processes important for assessing seismic hazards. In particular the pattern of normal faults reveals the stress field developed from seamount subduction in an erosional/non-accretionary subduction system. This stress field is critical for understanding subduction thrust stress accumulation with seamount and ridge collision and how they can affect earthquakes. We can also use these results to infer how materials are moved during collisions with the ridges/seamounts and how it contributes to the erosional process. We have quantified how much the upper plate is fractured from seamount collision, which will improve our understanding of fluid migration through the overriding plate and how it potentially changes stress accumulation and earthquake and tsunami potential along the subduction zone megathrust. Our results will enable future work to compare our results with other subduction zones and further characterize megathrust slip behavior and earthquake and tsunami hazards.
